title: Commercial drivers in Sunyani buy fuel at specific outlets
text:
Business & Finance | 8 August 2015 11:00 CET Commercial drivers in Sunyani buy fuel at specific outlets By GNA 
Sunyani, Aug. 6, GNA - Varying prices in petroleum products have informed the choice of many commercial drivers to buy the product from specific Oil Marketing Companies (OMCs) in the Sunyani Municipality. 
A visit by the Ghana News Agency (GNA) to some of the OMCs in the Brong-Ahafo Regional capital revealed that prices in petrol and diesel continued to drop marginally. 
Prices of petrol range between GHÈ¼3.31 pesewas and GHÈ¼3.42 pesewas per litre, while that of diesel go between GHÈ¼2.89 pesewas and GHÈ¼2.99 pesewas a litre. 
According to most of the drivers, they buy the product from the Ghana Oil Company (GOIL) which sells a litre of petrol at GHÈ¼3.31 pesewas, instead of the previous price of GHÈ¼3.42 pesewas. Price of diesel has also reduced from GHÈ¼2.98 pesewas to GHÈ¼2.89 pesewas. 
In a random interview, the drivers told the GNA that a gallon of petrol, which contained about 4.50 litres, was sold at GHÈ¼15.00 at Goil, with the same litres going for more than that price at other OMCs. 
They, however, mentioned that despite the drop in fuel prices, lorry fares remained unchanged. 
Kofi Ansu, a taxi driver who plies the Sunyani-Abesim road, said drivers had resolved not to reduce the fares because a downward review would affect them due to the unstable nature of the fuel prices. 
Interestingly at all the taxi ranks, as well as the different unions under the Ghana Private Road and Transport Union (GPRTU) and the Progressive Transport Owners Association (PROTOA) at the main Bosoma lorry park, the drivers' main concern was about the stability of the price of the commodity. 
They explained that that determined the sustainability and profitable growth of the commercial transport business. 
Ironically the issue of environment regarding cleanliness, security and health and safety measures like availability of fire extinguishers and the attitude of the attendants at the fuel retail outlets was also the concern of some private vehicle owners interviewed by the GNA. 
But that was not a priority of most of the commercial drivers so long as the cost of petrol/diesel and other fuel products remained 'manageable' to keep them in business. 
Meanwhile, attendants at some of filling stations in the Municipality indicated that daily sales of the products kept decreasing because of the unstable nature of the prices. GNA Other Stories Follow Us ¡°If my body dies, let my body die, but do not let my country die.¡± Gbooza.com By: Gbooza.com
